Please notice that, rather than being "summarily declined"
(as you state), these recommendations are being held over so
they may be discussed more fully at the special meeting of the
Board which will be held within the next few weeks for the
express purpose of examining the basic philosophy and organization
of NAEB with regard to its services to television members, its
liaison with education generally, its status with the PCC, and
its working relationships with other groups active in educational
broadcasting. This meeting will be attended by members familiar
with the problems of both institutional and community stations,
as well as by advisers from other fields with whioh we work.
Since this meeting had been agreed upon previous to the discussion
of your proposals, it was only natural that they should be considered
in broad context rather than piecemeal. If you had been fully
aware of our plans, I do not see how you could have reacted In
this way to the Board1s treatment of your proposals.
Your point 3 states that "NAEB Is dominated by a group of
Midwestern Radio Stations with little interest in ETV and
apparently no interest in the community television stations."
This you reinforce later by saying that there has been "during
the past six years an Increasing tendency for the NAEB to become
more and more a Midwestern social club for radio operators."
These statements are obviously Incorrect. More and more
NAEB workshops and seminars are being devoted to television.
In fact, the Allerton Seminar, where the proposals referred
to in your letter were developed, was such a meetings we
secured the funds for it, planned it with the assistance of
men from both institutional and community stations, and invited
participation from all the educational television stations (including
community stations) then on the air. What is more, recent changes
on our Board of Directors (an increasing number of NAEB officers
and directors are responsible at home for television broadcasting),
the greater Involvement of television members (both community
and otherwise) on committee assignments, the nature of the
workshops and seminars we support, and our recent convention
programs all provide further evidence of NAEB* s consistent
Interest in educational television.
Surely you cannot be serious in saying that "the major
effort of the convention was devoted to the production of an
amateur theatrical." The talks by Raymond Wittcoff and Harold
